td.p: Thomson, John. Journal, Mackenzie River, 1800-1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0021

div.p: Saturday the 10th[.] In the afternoon a young Man came for Tobacco for the arrival of General Montgomery – sent him one foot[.] [A] short time after he arrived along with 9 other Fisher Men[,] gave them drams & pieces of Tobacco[.] They came from the Grand Lac & slept 5 nights from thence to come here – they say it is Martin that desired them to come to the Fort, & that he is gone in search of others that are further on[.] Received 127 Skins Credits, & Traded 21 skins mostly all Pichues – 3 origl Collets, 1 Nose, 1 skin of Grease & 1 stinking Placottis[.] They are a despicable looking set & Stink most abomnibaly of Fish, to all appearances they pass their whole Lives, doing nothing else but Fishing – all their cloathing consists of Carribou & Hare Skins[.]

Sunday the 11th[.] Gave out 172 skins on Credit & for nothing to General Montgomery, the value of 7 skins in triffles – with strict orders to employ less of their Time fishing &c[.] In the forenoon they went away, all promised to come again in the spring with their Credits &c[.] The hunters arrived[,] they brought 40 hares[.] Early in the afternoon Martin & his 2 young Men arrived, gave them drams & pieces of tobacco – he has made but a very poor expedition of it, for he has not brought a single Indian along with him – he says that he saw in all nine Lodges, the furthest 4 days March beyond the Grand Lac, but that they had not amongst them all a single skin – what few they had made in the Fall the Red knives from Martin Lake had already Traded from them – besides the did not give themselves much Trouble to look for skins but spent their Time according to their usual custom, that is Fishing[.] Martin says that he would have proceeded further on inquest of others – but as he was very Lame with a swelled knee, he was afraid to venture any further &c[.] I am certainly much disappointed in my expectations from the Indians of that quarter, for I had flattered with the hopes of getting from them by this Time at least 10 Packs – but in place of that I must content myself with only about 2 Packs[.] I am now fully convinced that the Indians who are in that quarter
